comments.commentBody:
> "As a graduate of a poor NYC public school, I can say with certainty that there's no greater detriment to learning than the environment in these schools, the anti-intellectual, anti-good behavior, peer-pressure every student feels. Changing this is far more important than more money, smaller classrooms and better teachers. And the only way to change that environment is to get all the 'bad' apples out of the schools, so the kids who want to learn can learn and so teachers can teach.

There's a simple solution. What we need is to split public schools in to two types : those with kids who are willing to do their work, be respectful and behave and those with all the kids who make it hard for the others"
* * * * * * *

BEST COMMENT ON THIS TOPIC out here, and I have read them all ! ! !
In reality, there is a way to get the kind of change that makes Finland so effective. Politically, there is not.

> "[Successful operations] see schools in a broader context, elevating the importance of wraparound services like health care, meals, shelter for homeless youth and support for parents needing skills to obtain jobs paying livable wages"

While this is a valid observation, in the real world, it is impossible to imagine that we would ever get enough additional money to effectively implement such an agenda
AND, sadly, it would be a certain expectation that if such money somehow flooded into the school system, much of it would be siphoned off into unproductive empire-building activities, nest-feathering, or areas of downright corruption

I am certain that we already collectively spend more than enough money for 90-95% of our students to get a quality education, and that a vast amount of the money we spend already is largely ineffective

HOW MUCH MONEY do you think we waste on School Districts endlessly re-inventing the wheel in curriculum development, and textbook battles designed to produce a right-wing, conservative slant to every area of study that is susceptible to such hi-jhacking

WHY is every district creating it's own testing systems?
FREQUENTLY we see samples of Test Questions our students that boggle the mind in terms of stupidity, and usually it is a stupidity that is of a liberal orientation
When educated adults look at the test questions our students face, there should be absolutely none, that have any type of 'cleverness' involved.

California Man, your knee-jerk reaction to a thoughtful commentary is so utterly predictable and completely wrong-headed. Why don't you do some research and give us reasonable suggestions instead of just spouting right-wing talking points? I doubt you even read the article...

As an African-American woman with two daughters in college and who attended middle school in Harlem prior to receiving an academic scholarship to attend a private boarding school in New England, I need to make two comments:

1) Black people need to be honest and talk about how education is not respected in poor black families. It's no longer a "way out". I grew up hearing that my grandparents in the South had to walk five miles to school each way! When I was in middle school in Harlem, the kids said I talked "white" and tried to shame me because I did my homework. Eventually, I was put in a class with students who were at the top the class and it was great.

2) I accompanied my nephew on a field trip to the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. The school is on Lenox Ave, which is East Flatbush, but is now called Prospect-Lefferts Gardens because white people have moved into the neighborhood. The teachers were white and from Marine Park. One comment about the kids misbehaving went this way, "My kids go to school in Marine Park".

The teachers had no lesson plan for these kids while they were touring the gardens. The trip was an excuse to let them run wild with little supervision. I took the time to ask each misbehaving child their name, what they wanted to be when they grew up and did they recognize any of the plants, trees or flowers in the gardens. Before long, they were quiet, inquisitive and holding my hands.

These kids act out in an effort to get attention and guidance.

BOVINE SCAT.

Every minute spent away from academic learning, the arts anf physical education are academics, is yet another minute further behind the rest of the world a student falls.

The time has come for an emphasis to be made on moral values, ethics ,principles and habits first .
Education should enable one to live a refined life.
Academic part should take a backseat now.
We need teachers who are genuinely interested in seeing the children blossom into fine men and women of great values.
The question is not of being educated in an elite school or not. Many of the leaders who have been to elite institutions have not been able to transform the minds of their people . If they really cared they would have focussed more on the type of education provided.
As for kids , they are impressionable , rather than the infrastructure and other amenties all they require is love , care and understanding, the three ingredients that would make them a success in all the spheres of life.
As a former enlisted soldier and a former commanding officer, no parents are not held accountable by the military for their children's behavior or achievements at school.

I would expect that most, if not all children in DoD schools have two parents, both of which value education and neither of which is a drug addict. That might account for a large portion of the success of such schools.
As an alum of a DOD school, I can say that kids sure thought their dads' commanding officers were told if a kid was a recurring problem.

The answer to public schools has already been demonstrared by the best public schools in the country, which are Department of Defense schools. If you investigate why that is so, you will have your answer. The complexities involved in student achievement, a safe place to live and attend school (a military base), adequate housing, exceptional support from the community and parental motivation and accountability (residents are accountable to the commanding officer for the student's and the parent's behavior). Education is a wholistic endeavor. Unless you control the externalities our children face, you won't educate them well. And that will take more than changing teachers and schools.

You're right that most teachers and competent, diligent, and caring. You're right that they can't fix the issues here, and that we shouldn't ask them to try, as they're already overworked and underpaid as it is.

That doesn't mean supports shouldn't be provided, or that they shouldn't be housed in the school buildings. It just means that additional staff should provide them rather than dumping more responsibilities on teachers.

How do you know nothing's changed? can you imagine the horror life must have been before the free meals etc. etc.? My grand father was a butcher in a small village in Iowa during the Great Depression. He went out of business because he couldn't stand to see the children starve. Tax payers could solve this problem, but the richest of them keep escaping via the Republican Party's war on the poor.

I was in graduate school in the early to mid 1970s. Papers akin to this essay with similar prescriptions were written back then. It is evident there are no easy fixes here.

Little has changed because idealistic ivory tower ideas seldom work in the real world, although authors like this one often form a mutual admiration society telling one another how great their latest proposed "innovation" is.

The most important factors in student success are stable homes and supportive parents who set high standards regarding what is expected in school and in life. Families don't have to be middle class to meet such standards, but that helps obviously. Poor immigrant children often have the bar set high at home and they meet it.

Basic integrity, being responsible and hard work are the norms conveyed. They expect the students to attend class, do their assignments and get good grades.

The fact schools and teachers can't fix broken homes, poverty, parents that don't value education and so forth...doesn't mean they don't care. But you can't ask the impossible of schools in my view, yet this professor and many other "experts" apparently continue to think you can.

But after 40-50 years of trying to help with free meals, supplies, tutoring, counseling and so forth, nothing much has changed. Fixing families and individual choices are the root issue. And schools and taxpayers can't fix those things. Most teachers really do care by the way, they are not the problem.
Exactly. Acknowledging this fact, and having the courage to state it so bluntly, may be the first step in appropriately addressing the problem.
Sounds like home away from home. If this is indeed the case, we should go to orphanages, which is the true import of this writer's column.

Thank you for pointing out that in many regions, ILLEGAL IMMIGRATION is a massive contributor to this problem.

What could we be doing for OUR OWN CHILDREN, if we did not have to educate 15% of the entire population of Mexico, too? for FREE?

Taught government, economics, both core and AP, to 12th graders in an urban high school in which more than 90% of students qualified for free lunches, and 30% to 50% of 12th graders did not speak English as their first language. Though 12th graders had passed state-mandated math, reading and writing tests through 10th grade, the preponderance of them read at or below 6th grade level. The unusual student could write complete sentences. As a result of their family and social backgrounds and current living conditions, most of these students struggled. Administration leaned hard on teachers to maintain "failure" rates of 10% or lower; otherwise, teachers risked non-renewal of contracts or reduction in pay. Administration-imposed teacher evaluations could be skewed by evaluators; 15% of a teacher's evaluation was based on student surveys; 35% was based on student performance on administration-prepared tests in which teacher input was minimal. Teacher resignations and retirements have run between 25% and 35% in this high school and 16 others with similar student bodies.

Some kids were certainly helped.

Your argument is that it's not worth what we pay for it if all of them weren't. I disagree, and I suggest those kids who've climbed out of poverty because they received necessary support would, too.

Dear Dean Carter:

How long we have Great Society, set asides, Head Start, etc. etc.?

Half a century?

Are the "disadvantaged", especially in inner cities better off since time of Civil Rights?

Was any progress proportional to effort and resources spent on it?

How much of redistribution of money will be honestly needed to say, cut teen pregnancy at inner cities by half? Cut 80% out of wedlock child births by half (especially knowing that the ideal of feminism: Who need a man? might be possible on comfortable middle class professional income not on typical inner city income?

Sadly, one of very lonely voices calling for African American community sense of responsibility, that of Bill Cosby, have been now silenced due to his own demons and deeds.

Okay, maybe that will get rid of some less effective teachers. How do you propose to replace them? Do you think that ending teacher tenure will help attract good, effective teachers to school districts where they receive no support and where they are paid less well than they would be in surrounding districts? As it stands, these are less desirable jobs already. You can't just get rid of ineffective teachers. You have to replace them with someone else. Who will those people be?

I am in my 60s and don't remember ANY male teachers when I went to school in the K-6 years (in 4 different states). Teaching was one of the approximately 4 occupations available to women when I was growing up, along with nursing, secretary and mommy.

I frankly correlate school failure with the rise of MBAs who want "metrics" for everything. Not everything that counts can be counted.

You raise a good point, and I think it is part of the reason boys are struggling and falling behind in our education system today.  There are other reasons, too, such as the fact that boys tend to learn verbal and fine motor skills slightly later than girls, and pushing them to learn to read and write the alphabet in pre-K is often setting them up for failure because they simply aren't ready.  A child who can't keep up figures out that he's a failure, and loses interest or acts out, which leads to more failure.  Many boys actually benefit from starting school a year later than girls.  Another factor is that schools have nearly eliminated physical activity by cutting recess and gym time, which gives boys no outlet for their energy, which leads to too many being diagnosed with ADHD and medicated when possibly the only medication they really need is the chance to run around more.

Indeed. I'm in my 50s, and we too had zero male teachers in elementary school. Didn't see any at all till junior high.

In contrast, my husband retired a few years ago from teaching elementary special ed, where he did have male colleagues. There were still more women than men teaching, but decidedly more men than when he, veh or I were in school.

So since there are MORE men teaching now, your point falls apart, JK.

Ms. Weiss:

Did you ever noticed that decades of our K-12 system falling behind, also in global comparison, has the same timing as massive feminization?

Then, while it is politically correct and even applauded when African American and liberal critics complain that inner city students "don't have models (i.e. teachers) who look like them" it is impossible to suggest that boys - who are more "at risk", failing, diagnosed - rightly or due to sexism - with ADHD, have male models/teachers in front of them.

My anecdotal evidence and experience with six our own children (some of the Presidential Scholars, i.e. PSAT score at 99.9%) is telling:

Our ES yearbook has photos of 78(!) female teachers and staffers and only 5 males, 2 of them janitors and 1 custodian.

If girls or selected minority would have to have such environment there will be a "movement" and protests and marches, TV talking heads and billions of dollars is programs. But I guess that, also with only 38% of college students being men, boys, i.e. white and Asian boys, have it good, enjoying supposed "privilege".

...but they need to be supplied. And schools are the logical place to do so.

This absolutely should NOT be a thing where teachers, already overburdened with responsibility, are given even more responsibilities. But it makes sense to offer services to needy kids in the school buildings, since the schools (at least, the remaining neighborhood schools that haven't been decimated by charters and other choice scams) are public buildings and the center of the kids' non-home communities.

With more resources, public education for the poor wouldn't be fixed.  Some kids would still fail to get the education they're offered.  But probably more would succeed, and it'd likely be worth the investment to offer them more of an opportunity.

Massive feminization and unionization of our public school systems are obstacles to any actual improvement, especially in global comparison.

Not that all students (and society) suffer, but especially boys suffer in such feminized "cutesy and sweet verbosity are welcomed", "running on a grass during rare break is verboten."

The kids are already born, and nobody's suggesting offering them "free stuff"--just more support so that they can, hopefully, learn and succeed for themselves.  No handouts, just opportunity.  Not all of them will take it.  But some will.

Not only pay is not that bad but lucrative pension is something that 95% of private sector had to forget about long time ago.

Than, unlike private sector, job security (even with some layoffs) is in K-12 teaching jobs much better and is a premium in this otherwise globally competitive market.

Compensating for the families' failure won't be completely successful, but it'll work for some kids.

It would cost money, though.

Let me guess: What schools or cities have "poisoned water"?

Flint, MI?
Bridgeport, CT?

How long and how much is the majority population, increasingly squeezed by global competitiveness, obligated to change habits, values of inner city fellow citizens so that their children have better chance to learn during school years?

Teen pregnancies, motherhood at 14, grandma at 30, 80% out of wedlock birth.
People in suburbs or how much more of their $$$ will, after 50 years of Great Society programs, really make a significant change in those fundamentals?
Actually, that's very local. I get paid pretty well out here. Back home in North Carolina? Forget that; I wouldn't be able to make rent.

Why?
How far the social engineering should go?
Why parents who commit themselves to expensive mortgage so that their kids can have decent schools should have their kids have the same school, same resources as those who are much, much less productive or unproductive at all?
That can help, but the charter school experiment shows that people who haven't had 4-6 years study of education aren't magically better teachers.

"very culturally diverse neighborhood"

Read: mostly minorities, specifically poor minorities.
Similar to "working class neighborhood": poor, high unemployment affected.

I teach in a poor area. Courtesy of my union, I'm paid rather well, even though the only work expectation of me is that I show up. While some parts of our country (the deep south) severely underpay their teachers, my being paid well doesn't magically make me a better teacher.
